title: The Golden Scheme
opening: While waiting for reinforcements, the Alliance predicts the Empire will continue to fortify its defenses at Fort Merceus. Knowing this risk, Claude an a select few advance, hoping to gain entry to the fort through deception.
Fort Merceus, said to be impregnable, lies between you and Enbarr, the Imperial Capital. Seizing the sturdy fortress will require a carefully devised strategy.

dialogue.speaker: Judith
dialogue.line: Our objective is Enbarr, the Imperial Capital. But our greatest obstacle lies before that.

dialogue.speaker: Ignatz
dialogue.line: And what's what?

dialogue.speaker: Judith
dialogue.line: Fort Merceus. If we can't pass through, we won't be able to reach Enbarr.

dialogue.speaker: Leonie
dialogue.line: Fort Merceus... the Impregnable Fortress, or so it's called.

dialogue.speaker: Ignatz
dialogue.line: If I recall correctly, it's sometimes referred to as the Stubborn Old General.

dialogue.speaker: Lysithea
dialogue.line: It is a massive fortress that was constructed to protect the Imperial capital.

dialogue.speaker: Shamir
dialogue.line: The Imperial army we defeated has withdrawn to Enbarr. Fort Merceus should be short on soldiers for now.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: We should attack quickly.

dialogue.speaker: Judith
dialogue.line: Yes, it would be good to finish up here before more enemy reinforcements arrive.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: We should be careful.

dialogue.speaker: Judith
dialogue.line: It would be best to take it before enemy reinforcements arrive. Still, there's a reason it's been called impregnable.

dialogue.speaker: Judith
dialogue.line: The only real question is what our fearless leader intends to do...

dialogue.speaker: Claude
dialogue.line: Sorry for the delay, everyone. Those mewling lords kept me from leaving for quite some time.

dialogue.speaker: Judith
dialogue.line: So? Were you able to secure additional reinforcements?

dialogue.speaker: Claude
dialogue.line: It's gonna have to wait until next month. It doesn't look like they can afford to keep supporting us at present.

dialogue.speaker: Judith
dialogue.line: Then what should we do about Fort Merceus? Do you plan on waiting around?

dialogue.speaker: Claude
dialogue.line: No. If we wait until next month, the enemy will have bolstered their defenses. That said, the prevailing theory is that you need triple your enemies' forces to take a fortress with a frontal assault.

dialogue.speaker: Leonie
dialogue.line: Right, that's what we were taught at the academy. And this is Fort Merceus we're talking about. It's renowned for its strong defenses.

dialogue.speaker: Claude
dialogue.line: Our current army isn't nearly strong enough. Hmm... What to do...

dialogue.speaker: Judith
dialogue.line: Whatever you do, just don't ask us to scale those huge walls. We'd end up dead when they hurl rocks down at us.

dialogue.speaker: Hilda
dialogue.line: Yeah, no thanks! If only someone would open up the gates for us from the inside.

dialogue.speaker: Claude
dialogue.line: Unfortunately we don't have any spies in there. Wait a minute... I've got it! We sneak in, stir up confusion, and open the gates ourselves to let our allies in.

dialogue.speaker: Hilda
dialogue.line: Right! That's what I was saying all along!

dialogue.speaker: Ignatz
dialogue.line: Right. Nice one, Hilda. But how do you propose we go about sneaking in?

dialogue.speaker: Hilda
dialogue.line: Disguises? If we dress up like Imperial soldiers, maybe they'll think we're allies and let us in!

dialogue.speaker: Leonie
dialogue.line: Do you really think they'd just open the gates for us? I'd be pretty dumbfounded if that worked.

dialogue.speaker: Claude
dialogue.line: No, no - she's on to something. It's a good idea, Hilda. We just need to refine it a bit, and we'll be in there before we know it.

dialogue.speaker: Hilda
dialogue.line: Really? Go me!

dialogue.speaker: Lorenz
dialogue.line: What is your definition of refining the idea? I know your go-to strategy is nausea-inducing poison, but...

dialogue.speaker: Raphael
dialogue.line: Urgh! I maybe ate too much. My stomach hurts...

dialogue.speaker: Lorenz
dialogue.line: Raphael... Why are you eating meat during a war council?!

dialogue.speaker: Judith
dialogue.line: So, fearless leader, I'm guessing you're going to keep the crucial parts of your scheme under wraps until the time comes, aren't you?

dialogue.speaker: Claude
dialogue.line: You know me so well, Judith. Whether we like it or not, this war puts a damper on all of our spirits. What's wrong with trying to have a little fun every now and again? Just leave the details to me.

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: Each time we take a step forward, more blood is spilled… but by spilling that blood, we're able to take yet another step forward. War is always a cruel affair, but luckily we have each other to lean on. We've steeled our hearts. We won't be broken.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I'm glad we have such reliable allies.

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: I couldn't agree more. Without them, we could never have made it this far.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I wonder if we're pushing them too hard.

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: If anyone's starting to feel the strain, I'm sure just hearing from you will reassure them. Please… do whatever you can to keep their morale up.

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: Oh, and about taking the fort… I'll need a tad more time to prepare our plan. It's called an impregnable fortress for a reason, after all. My contingencies need contingencies this time, or we might not pull it off.

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: Fort Merceus is old and strong. Its reputation for durability is equal to that of Arianrhod. Are we really going to leave this to Claude? With a plan concocted by Hilda, of all people?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I'm uneasy too.

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: I thought you might be, with how secretly that man devises his schemes.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Have a little faith.

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: I would like to, but I am always troubled by how secretly that man devises his schemes.

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: Let us hope the end result is not too outlandish.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: You know when you work your muscles and they start screaming? That means you gotta be nice to them. If your muscles are hungry, you gotta feed them, and let them rest when they're tired.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I don't see how you'd do that.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Whaddya mean, how? You just gotta eat and sleep! It's pretty obvious...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You can tell how your muscles are feeling?

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Of course! If my muscles hurt, then I hurt. If they're hungry, well then I'm hungry too!

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: What's with the confused face, Professor? You look like you don't get a word I'm saying!

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: The battle at Gronder Field was gruesome, wasn't it? But perhaps it's irresponsible to look away - to close our eyes to the horrors of war.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I agree.

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: As survivors, we must ensure that all these lives were not lost in vain. We must see the tragic foundations upon which we'll build our future.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You don't have to force yourself.

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: Thank you. But I think I do actually. As survivors, we must ensure that all these lives were not lost in vain. We must see the tragic foundations upon which we'll build our future.

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: May an age of peace rise from the ashes, so that all this sacrifice means something.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: As I suspected, they seem to be supporting the Imperial army now. Thought I don't quite know who they are yet… Nor do I know what tricks they'll use against us next. We can't afford to let our guard down…

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: I never used to care whether I lived or died… But after seeing so much death firsthand, I now realize how precious life truly is. I'm ashamed of how arrogant I was to think that death could mean so little…

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: I wonder how far we can get with this plan. Dressing up like Imperial soldiers to sneak in. Claude said it could use some refinement. Any ideas?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We could dress you as the emperor.

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: Dress me as Edelgard?! But we look nothing alike!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We could dress Claude as a woman.

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: Claude, dressed as a woman? I don't understand what the point of that would be.

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: On second thought, let's just stick to the plan as originally conceived. That seems safer.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: Claude takes care of the strategy, you direct the troops, and the rest of us focus on the fighting. As long as the system keeps working, we can win any battle, no matter the odds. That's what everyone's saying anyway. Hope you can keep up with our expectations, Professor.

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: Dimitri, the late Prince of Faerghus. He despised the Empire with all his heart. He should not have tried leading an army while his emotions were holding him captive.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Leaders are people too.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Leaders can't be emotional?

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: No. If a leader's emotions overcome them, others must step in to prevent poor decision-making. Why did his followers not intervene? His attendants? I used to call Edelgard my leader, and now she is running amok. I am duty-bound to stop her.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: There's word that Claude has developed a rather interesting stratagem to capture the fortress. You know Fort Merceus's nickname, I assume. The Stubborn Old General? But there must be one or two gaps in its defenses...

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: Fort Merceus is next, huh? Ah, the memories. It's a huge stronghold in my father's domain. The town's completely surrounded by high walls. I used to run around there when I was a kid... Way back when a fortress was just a playground for me. Yeah, those were the days.

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: It's always relaxing coming back here. But it's hard to relax knowing we have to go out on another expedition again so soon. And assaulting that huge keep? That sounds hard. Oh, really hard! Don't you think it'll be hard?!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It's going to be tough.

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: I knew you'd think so! I knew you-- Ow! Oh, ow. Can't believe I tried to hug you through the door.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We'll be fine.

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: Of course you'd say that. Why did I even bother asking?

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: So many people died in the battle at Gronder... And here we are, preparing for the next battle, as if nothing happened the day before. It's almost easier to think of war as theater, with the stage an entire continent.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Though the actors die, the show goes on?

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: Something like that. If an accident happens on stage, the next day's performance must unaffected.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It really doesn't seem like theater.

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: Even if an accident happens on stage, the next day you have to sing as though nothing happened.

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: Everyone just pretends like everything is fine... focusing on their role in the play.

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: I have excitement in my heart for secret tactics! I enjoy attacks that are surprising.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Why's that?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Because it's like hunting?

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: Yes. Hunting is doing surprise attacks on prey.

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: Surprise attacks are safe with friends. Fewer injuries.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: My relationship with the boar prince began even before I was born. He was always by my side. You might even say that, at one time, we were best friends.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: What do you mean, best friends?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: What happened?

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: I couldn't fathom the depth of his hatred for the Empire. So much anguish. Could I have saved him? Could I have stopped him?

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: I've heard Dedue's passed on. Just like His Highness.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We can't know that for certain.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: That's true. I did hear that his body was never found.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Don't believe everything you hear.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: You're right. I don't think anyone's found his body, so I guess he might still be out there.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Dedue is dead?

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: That's what I've heard, but no one's found his body.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: If, somehow, he's still alive...I hope we'll meet again.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Ya know, Professor, laying siege to a keep is like asking a girl out on a date. First, you get past her defenses...then you make your move.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That's not the best analogy.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Trust me, I know what I'm talking about. I'm a seasoned veteran at this kind of thing. Girls, I mean. I've never actually, you know, captured any keeps...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You might be right.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Ha! I knew you'd get it, Professor.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Anyway, you know more about tactics than me, so I don't know why I'm offering you advice.

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: Oh, Goddess, hear my prayer. Please bless the deceased with peace everlasting...And may his soul rest in tranquility. You know, I used to see him praying quite often when I would come to the cathedral at night. I wonder who it was he prayed for back then...

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: After the battle at Gronder, some people claim they saw my father. They said he walked off the battlefield clutching… His Highness's dead body… So long as Father's alive, I don't need anything else. I just… I hope to see him again one day…

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Among our prisoners of war, there were quite a few people who served His Highness. One of them stated that the Empire was involved with the Tragedy of Duscur. If this is true, His Highness's motives seem clear. I can't help but feel that perhaps I should have fought by his side…

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Why is that?

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Because…I, too, lost someone to that tragedy—the most important person in my world.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Are you having regrets?

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: No. Not anymore. I am where I belong.

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Those of us still on this plane of existence will carry the torch. The inhumane actions of the Empire must not be repeated.

conversation.speaker: Seteth
conversation.line: Fort Merceus is a keep that was constructed to defend the Imperial Capital, Enbarr. We cannot enter the capital without first capturing that fort. But once we have it, the city should be almost entirely at our mercy. Whatever strategy you have in mind, I have faith that it will lead to victory.

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: Standing face to face with those whom I went to school with. On the field of battle… How inhuman war is - how horrifying. My heart feels shattered. It is my hope that this war marks the end of such foolish behavior.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: Fort Merceus is the Empire's single most fortified military installation. Utterly impregnable, they say. I wonder, do you happen to know the nickname given to Fort Merceus?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: The Silver Maiden.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: No, I'm afraid that name refers to the Fortress City of Arianrhod.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Fódlan's Locket.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: That one is a fortress that stands at Fódlan's Throat.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: The Stubborn Old General.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: Indeed! A very good answer, but of course you'd know that.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: Seems Fódlans give everyone and everything a nickname. Why, you were called the Ashen Demon! Myself, I have been called the Father of Crestology, which is a nickname as well as a title, I suppose...

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: Each step closer to Enbarr, I'm reminded of another part of my past. Riches and poverty, glory and failure, that city has it all! And if I'm honest... sometimes I miss it. That's how the past works though, isn't it? It's always a different story than what you really lived.

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: Hilda's quite a tactician! Disguising ourselves as enemy soldiers to sneak in, undetected. A stroke of brilliance. With this strategy, we can really snatch victory from the jaws of...deceit!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That's a good point.

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: Yes... With you leading our fighters, I've no doubt the Empire will suffer an embarrassing deceit. Get it? Deceit? Again?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That's a bad pun.

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: Ah, rats! You've seen through my cunning punning!

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: I hardly recognize everyone... Their faces have changed so much. More experience in the eyes, and more pain. I'm glad that they're stronger, but I hate to think that they've all become hardened killers. Look after them, OK? Try to keep 'em on the straight-and-narrow.

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: Please tell Claude not to give us any more ridiculous orders. I've reached out through all of my channels, but there are limits to these things. I'll have to recruit an entire town's worth of people if I ever plan on making enough Imperial uniforms.

conversation.speaker: Cyril
conversation.line: Guess what I noticed. I can see further than most other people can see. But I can't figure the point of seeing further than an arrow can fly, since I can't shoot what I see.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You could detect enemy movements in advance.

conversation.speaker: Cyril
conversation.line: I suppose I could see a whole horde of enemies coming and run away. That's kinda useful, at least.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You could find our targets quicker than anyone.

conversation.speaker: Cyril
conversation.line: Yeah, I suppose it could be real useful for finding Lady Rhea too.

conversation.speaker: Cyril
conversation.line: Thanks, Professor. I think I get it now. I'm gonna put my eyes to real good use.

conversation.speaker: Judith
conversation.line: Ah, Professor. I have a question for you… Have you heard of the Death Knight? I'm referring to that Imperial general who has been operating under that moniker.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I've heard of him.

conversation.speaker: Judith
conversation.line: Nothing is certain yet, but I get the feeling we'll have to face him soon enough.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I haven't heard of him.

conversation.speaker: Judith
conversation.line: Well now… I don't know very much myself. Only that he's caused a great deal of havoc in the west. Nothing is certain yet, but I get the feeling we'll have to face him soon enough.

conversation.speaker: Gatekeeper
conversation.line: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! Is it true that we'll be assaulting Fort Merceus next? That doesn't sound like the brightest idea... I've heard that it's built to withstand an attack from even the largest of armies! Not to tell you how to do your job, but don't do it! I'm not ready to say my final good-byes to everyone...

intro.speaker: Ignatz
intro.line: I delivered our letter to Fort Merceus. I don't think they suspected anything.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: I knew I was right to entrust that task to you. You've got that honest kind of face that makes it easy to fool people.

intro.speaker: Ignatz
intro.line: Is that meant to be a compliment?

intro.speaker: Lysithea
intro.line: What did you write in the letter?

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: I informed them that reinforcements were on the way. It would have been suspicious for troops to show up unannounced.

intro.speaker: Hilda
intro.line: So, the plan is...

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: We'll disguise ourselves as reinforcements from the Imperial capital and sneak in to Fort Merceus.

intro.speaker: Hilda
intro.line: Oh! You used my disguise plan after all!

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: We've also procured Imperial army uniforms.

intro.speaker: Hilda
intro.line: Ooh, good work. I knew this was the only way!

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: However... That alone wouldn't be enough.

intro.speaker: Hilda
intro.line: You did say the plan needed a little more refinement. Are you going to dress up like Edelgard, Claude?

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: I'm not sure that would accomplish much. In the letter, I included the name of the Imperial general leading the reinforcements. While we're heading to the fort, a separate army is going to attack us.

intro.speaker: Marianne
intro.line: We're going to be attacked?!

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: That's all just for show, though. It'll be our allies who are attacking us.

intro.speaker: Hilda
intro.line: Oh, I get it! We're going to make it look like the Alliance is attacking Imperial reinforcements!

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: Right. When the troops in the fortress panic and open up the gates... We're in.

intro.speaker: Judith
intro.line: I'd love nothing more than for this plan to work, but I've got some bad news for you. Apparently the notorious Death Knight has been placed in charge of defending Fort Merceus.

intro.speaker: Marianne
intro.line: The one who kidnapped Flayn...

intro.speaker: Flayn
intro.line: The Death Knight... I did not wish to ever think of him again.

intro.speaker: Judith
intro.line: He got some acclaim in the battle to subjugate western Faerghus. They say he holds the most military prowess in the Empire.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: Even so, we've got Teach here to command us. All will be well. You have to trust us.

intro.speaker: Judith
intro.line: So your big plan is to just trust your professor? Really, boy?

intro.speaker: Leonie
intro.line: Under the professor's guidance, I'm sure we'll manage somehow. We're counting on the tactics you learned from Captain Jeralt!

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: Prepare yourselves, everyone. It's time.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: Teach... This is for your ears only, but there's actually one more part to my plan. I had hoped it wouldn't come to this, but I have no choice.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: No choice?

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: Absolutely. We can't afford to hold anything back. Thanks to Edelgard's strength, the Imperial army is more unified than I would have expected. It was a painful realization, but after our battle at Gronder Field, it's clear that we can't win if we don't pull out all the stops. I also realized something else during that battle. There really is something special about you, Teach. The reason we were all able to keep our cool in the midst of the chaos was because we all trust in you. In your command and in your strength. Everyone here believes that we will win as long as we have you on our side. Our faith in you is borderline religious. You and I... We have what it takes to free Fódlan from the Empire's rule. I know in my heart that we'll make it through to witness the world after all the fighting has ceased.

intro.speaker: Death Knight
intro.line: That man/woman approaches...

intro.speaker: Caspar
intro.line: Who are you talking about? You don't mean that professor, do you?! Doesn't matter. No one could take this fortress.

intro.speaker: Linhardt
intro.line: Ugh, sounds like a bother... I'll be taking a nap about now.

intro.speaker: Death Knight
intro.line: Will death's scythe claim you... Or will I fall to that sword of yours...

battle.speaker: Claude
battle.line: An impregnable fortress is a wide-open prairie once you get inside. From here, we'll attack from the north and south at once!

battle.speaker: Nader
battle.line: No different than a prairie, you say? Heh! You've got a strange head on your shoulders, kiddo

battle.speaker: Claude
battle.line: For Nader the Undefeated, this should be as easy as a walk in a meadow, right?

battle.speaker: Nader
battle.line: Heh. Well, goddess or death god or whoever they may be, let's crush them to dust.

battle.speaker: Death Knight
battle.line: The time of ruin draws near... But their slaughter must wait until next we meet...

battle.speaker: Alliance Soldier
battle.line: Report! The Death Knight has escaped the fortress!

battle.speaker: Claude
battle.line: He gave up too easily. Does he have some other plan? Let's deal with the remaining enemies and go after him, quickly!

battle.speaker: Alliance Soldier
battle.line: Report! The Death Knight is moving! It looks like they're abandoning the fortress and making an escape!

battle.speaker: Claude
battle.line: We need to put an end to this here and now. Come on, let's circle around and cut off his retreat.

cutscene.speaker: Nader
cutscene.line: I see your skills haven't dulled yet, kiddo.

cutscene.speaker: Claude
cutscene.line: Everyone, listen up! From now on, the Almyran forces will be fighting by our side!

cutscene.speaker: Claude
cutscene.line: We'll work as one! And we will bring down that fort together!

boss.speaker: Claude
boss.line: Hey, how long's it been? Five years? Who'd have thought you'd end up an Imperial general...

boss.speaker: Claude
boss.line: Heh. As antisocial and unhinged as ever, I see.

end.speaker: Nader
end.line: Hey, kiddo! What was with that... javelin of... light?

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Javelin of light... That describes it pretty well. The fortress was supposedly impregnable, but look at it now.It's hard to imagine that the Empire would do something like that. But if not them, then who? And for what purpose? If they wanted to kill us, then why wait until now to use it?

end.speaker: Judith
end.line: We almost died just now... and without an answer to any of that. Speaking of unanswered questions, why is Nardel here? Care to explain? I get the feeling there's something you two are keeping from us.

end.speaker: Nader
end.line: I'll go ahead and see my subordinates off to Almyra, kiddo.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Wait, Nader! Are really going to just leave me here and run away?

end.speaker: Nader
end.line: I hope to see you again, Judith. And you too, Professor. I'll be praying for your safety!

end.speaker: Judith
end.line: Nader? Are you saying that Nardel is actually Nader the Unstoppable?!

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Unstoppable?

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: It's actually Nader the Undefeated. Almyrans love grand titles.

end.speaker: Judith
end.line: I knew he was no ordinary person, but to think he was the great hero of Almyra...

end.speaker: Hilda
end.line: Hey, um, can we really afford to be chatting right now? If another one of those javelins of light falls, we're all dead!

end.speaker: Lorenz
end.line: Claude. There are things I wish to ask you, but first we must hurry and withdraw.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Right you are. Come on, everyone! Let's hurry up and get out of here.

end.speaker: Lorenz
end.line: Claude. It is time for you to explain. Why are you so close with an Almyran general?

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Well, he did quite a bit for me when I was younger.

end.speaker: Lorenz
end.line: When you were younger... So, before you joined House Riegan. How and where did you meet him? There aren't many opportunities to meet a general from Almyra in Fódlan...

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: If that's what you believe, it's only because that's what you've been led to believe. After all, we have Cyril here among our allies, and he was born in Almyra.

end.speaker: Cyril
end.line: Hey, now. Don't drag me into this.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: There's a big, wide world outside of Fódlan, and it's overflowing with different places and cultures. You think interacting with outsiders is odd, but isn't avoiding contact with the outside world far more unnatural?

end.speaker: Lorenz
end.line: Don't change the subject, Claude. To the people of the Alliance, the Almyrans are-

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: It's true that there's a history of hostility, but why should that mean we're doomed to remain hostile forever? The Almyrans aren't monsters. Just look at Cyril! Does he look like a monster to you?

end.speaker: Cyril
end.line: Hey, what's that supposed to mean?

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Right, Teach? What did you think when you met Nader?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: He's... interesting.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: He's a reliable general.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Ha! I'll tell him you said that. And I'm sure that if all of you got to know him, all of your preconceived notions would change too. I know you guys, and you aren't the type of people to reject someone without trying to get to know them.

end.speaker: Hilda
end.line: But... how did those Almyrans even get past Fódlan's Throat? I doubt my brother would just let them pass without saying anything...

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: About that... I actually made sure your brother met Nader in advance.

end.speaker: Lorenz
end.line: What?! Lord Holst met with an Almyran general?

end.speaker: Hilda
end.line: Oh, so that's why you were so interested in my brother. But wait, they're supposed to be bitter enemies! They've fought each other several times before!

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: I know. It was a big gamble. But rather than having me try to convince them myself, I knew it would be easier to just have them meet. They were taken aback at first, but sure enough, they hit it off. They were even drinking to their newfound brotherhood before parting.

end.speaker: Judith
end.line: It makes sense. If you take the greatest heroes away from the battlefield, of course they'll get along.

end.speaker: Hilda
end.line: Fighting one minute and drinking together the next... Men are so weird!

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Ultimately, someone's bloodline has nothing to do with the friendships they forge. Relations between the Alliance and Almyra is a matter we'll tackle in the future. Still, I want to take this opportunity to make one thing clear to all of you. After we defeat the Empire, I intend to tear down the walls that separate Fódlan from the outside world. I want to let people and goods come and go freely, and in doing so, eradicate prejudices about the outside world.

end.speaker: Cyril
end.line: Huh?!

end.speaker: Lorenz
end.line: Would it even be possible to achieve such a thing? It directly contradicts the Seiros tenets.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Does it? I'm not so sure. I'm any case, I'm prepared for the inevitable protests and criticism. New ways of doing things are always met with resistance. During our time at the Officer's Academy, all of you overcame the barriers of birthplace, status, and ideology. Having gone through so much with all of you, I have no doubt that, in time, you'll understand.

end.speaker: Hilda
end.line: I guess there were a lot of different people there. People we wouldn't have met through the normal course of our lives.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Duscur once opposed the Kingdom, but there was someone from Duscur there. Brigid once invaded the Empire, but the Brigid princess was there. We ate at the same table as those people. Sure, sometimes we didn't get along. But other times, we helped each other out. Can we really draw a definitive line in the sand and say one group of people is all good, and another all bad? If I can realize my dream, Fódlan will be reborn. The old age will end and we'll welcome a new dawn.

end.speaker: Lorenz
end.line: But, if-

end.speaker: Judith
end.line: Save your objections for another day, Gloucester boy.

end.speaker: Lorenz
end.line: Ugh...

end.speaker: Judith
end.line: That said, there are more pressing matters to discuss. Our next step is to invade the Imperial capital, right?

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: That's right. I'm sure Edelgard is eagerly awaiting our arrival in Enbarr. Reinforcements from the Alliance lords should arrive soon. Let's make sure we're ready to greet them.
